Athletics at Johns Hopkins during 1923 made rapid strides. The
track Steam, with two stars of the first magnitude, attracted national
attention and startled the country's sport fans by scoring twelve
points, a hitherto unprecedented count for a small college, at the I. C.
A. A. A. A. meet in Philadelphia. The lacrosse team, by capturing
the Southern Intercollegiate Lacrosse Title, brought renown to Hopkins.
The 1923 football team, however, with no championship to its
credit, was the pride of the University. With mediocre material,
Coach Van. Orman entered the season greatly handicapped. The
team held Princeton 16-7 and lost to Cornell by a large score. Although all other games were w,on, the Black and Blue entered the
Maryland contest without being conceded a chance. How Maryland only succeeded in tying the score in the dying moments of the
game is a matter of history. Suffice to say, Hopkins gained more
friends on Thanksgiving Day, 1923, than ever before in its history.
Non-athletic activities, too, contributed to the general trend of
improvements and progress. Noteworthy events in this line included
the introduction of an elaborate and successful June Week, the enlargement of the activities of the Dramatic Club as "Barnstormers"
and marked extension in the work of the hitherto dormant Publicity
Board.
1924 lies before us as a blank pad of pure white paper. The
progress of 1923 was not so extensive as to prevent further advancement. More buildings, especially a gymnasium, are needed. Athletic and non-athletic activities may be brought closer to the standards in vogue at large colleges. And it is the undergraduate body

Athletics at Johns Hopkins during 1923 made rapid strides. The
track Steam, with two stars of the first magnitude, attracted national
attention and startled the country's sport fans by scoring twelve
points, a hitherto unprecedented count for a small college, at the I. C.
A. A. A. A. meet in Philadelphia. The lacrosse team, by capturing
the Southern Intercollegiate Lacrosse Title, brought renown to Hopkins.
The 1923 football team, however, with no championship to its
credit, was the pride of the University. With mediocre material,
Coach Van. Orman entered the season greatly handicapped. The
team held Princeton 16-7 and lost to Cornell by a large score. Although all other games were w,on, the Black and Blue entered the
Maryland contest without being conceded a chance. How Maryland only succeeded in tying the score in the dying moments of the
game is a matter of history. Suffice to say, Hopkins gained more
friends on Thanksgiving Day, 1923, than ever before in its history.
Non-athletic activities, too, contributed to the general trend of
improvements and progress. Noteworthy events in this line included
the introduction of an elaborate and successful June Week, the enlargement of the activities of the Dramatic Club as "Barnstormers"
and marked extension in the work of the hitherto dormant Publicity
Board.
1924 lies before us as a blank pad of pure white paper. The
progress of 1923 was not so extensive as to prevent further advancement. More buildings, especially a gymnasium, are needed. Athletic and non-athletic activities may be brought closer to the standards in vogue at large colleges. And it is the undergraduate body
